zone.line: So
Soc.--Hail to thee Ion, comest thou
whence returnest thou
amongst us; from thine own native Ephesus?
Ion--From Epidauras, o Socrates, of the Ã†scula
-pians.--S. Had the Epidaurians instituted a
rhapsodists
contest of raphsodists to the honor of the god?
Ion. And not that alone, but contests in
every species of mus musical art. Soc.
And what prize didst thou gain, & how
did you gain it? And into what contest
did you enter, & what was the event of
your efforts. Ion. I carried the first prize
you have only to consider
[?how]
o Socrates. Socrates. Well done, [how] you will
shall
bear away the Panath{e}nea, [too] next.--
Ion. That also may happen if the {G}od
should be propitious. S. I have often
on account
envied you rhapsodists, o Ion, for the
delicacy for for
Elegance of your art{;} it imposes on you
[first]
the nicest nicest care of your persons
& the most studied elegance of dress
so that you must appear most
